g.text: A linear data structure that follows Last In First Out (LIFO) principle
Elements are added and removed from the same end called "TOP"
Stack of plates, pile of books, browser back button, function call stack
return stack[-1] if stack else None
Returns top element without removing it
Returns number of elements in stack
Shows stack contents from top to bottom
Step by step conversion using operator stack:
Final Postfix: A B C * + D -
Each function call is pushed onto the call stack
Returns are popped in LIFO order
Push opening brackets, pop for closing brackets
• O(1) time complexity for push and pop operations
• Memory efficient - only stores what's needed
• Limited access - only top element accessible
• No random access to middle elements
• Stack overflow risk with too many elements
Stack is a fundamental data structure essential for many algorithms and system operations
Key Applications: Expression Evaluation | Function Calls | Undo Operations | Syntax Parsing | Backtracking Algorithms
